4.50.text:
As Paul was meant to
say, I'm Mat Scales.

7.34.text:
I'm on Google's Web
Developer Relations team,

9.93.text:
and I'm here to talk to you
about tools and libraries

17.53.text:
Part of what makes
progressive web apps possible,

20.37.text:
now, is a shift in the way
that the platform itself

25.60.text:
On the old web, we got custom
designed, high level features

29.37.text:
for achieving things
that W3C thought

33.92.text:
Developers want images, so
we'll give them an image tag.

36.26.text:
Developers want to lay
things out in tables,

38.09.text: so we'll have a table tag.

41.36.text:
The new idea is this thing
called the Extensible Web,

44.24.text:
and it says that rather
than building simple APIs

47.50.text:
for specific things,
we should be getting

50.32.text:
low level, deep,
powerful APIs that enable

53.04.text: a much broader range of things.

56.22.text:
So, rather than
a tag for images,

57.59.text:
let's have a tag for
arbitrary graphics.

59.53.text:
Rather than a tag tables,
let's have CSS properties

63.00.text:
that let's us lay things
out however we want.

67.81.text:
This is great, and it allows us
to upgrade our pages into apps,

70.51.text:
but there's this gap between
the level the platform gives us

73.83.text:
and the level we'd
like to work at.

75.29.text:
And we can fill that
gap with libraries.

81.91.text:
In the Extensible
Web, the community

84.02.text:
is given the responsibility of
providing simple, easy to use

87.66.text:
libraries to handle the specific
things that developers actually

91.11.text:
want to do, and this is great
because it's much easier

94.66.text:
to iterate on the
API of a library

96.81.text:
than it is to iterate
the web platform itself.

100.18.text:
This means that
even as we speak,

101.91.text:
someone is out there
solving hard problems

104.23.text: so that you don't have to.

108.79.text:
Today, I'm going to talk
about libraries and tools

113.30.text:
I'm going to talk
about the new web app

118.30.text:
I'm also going to try
and answer the question

120.17.text:
of is the thing that I built
actually a progressive web app,

123.44.text:
and is there anything
else I need to do?

128.92.text:
Obviously, the most
important new technologies

130.84.text:
as far as progressive
web apps are

134.24.text:
Just a quick recap,
a service worker

136.33.text:
is a background thread
for your application.

138.16.text:
It opens up new features
like offline push messaging

145.35.text:
For the offline use case,
it acts as a network proxy

150.61.text:
So whenever your page
requests a resource,

153.61.text:
the service worker gets a chance
to respond to that request.

158.10.text:
It gets a chance to get in the
way and do whatever it wants.

162.84.text:
And also, just to
remind you, this

168.60.text:
because even being online
can be a terrible experience.

171.64.text:
If you have Li-Fi,
or if you just

173.70.text:
have a slow connection, maybe
connecting to hotel Wi-Fi,

177.73.text:
or maybe you're somewhere where
data costs a lot of money,

180.83.text:
what you really want is
network independence.

184.92.text:
You want the
experience of your app

186.56.text:
to be great regardless
of the network situation.

191.97.text:
But in order to achieve
that, compact apps

195.17.text:
are going to require pretty
complex service workers.

197.73.text:
There'll be a lot of code,
and there's a lot of new APIs

201.32.text:
So, we're going to help
with that with a library

203.32.text:
we built called Service Worker
Tool Box, or SW-Toolbox.

208.17.text:
This was created by
our team at Google

210.61.text:
to abstract away
the common patterns

217.74.text:
Here's a pretty simple example
of a service worker written

223.78.text:
You import the script from
wherever it's residing,

228.79.text:
and that gives you a
global object called

Here we call
toolbox.precache, and we

238.36.text: pass in a list of resources.

This says that when our
service worker is installed,

243.16.text:
go ahead, fetch all these
things, stick them in a cache

246.23.text:
so that we know that whenever
our service worker is running,

249.14.text:
it has access to
these resources.

251.24.text:
And you use the app shell and
perhaps any really common,

Then we use toolbox.router
to match different behavior

to different parts
of our application.

So here, we're going

We're going to say that the

And here, you can see just
an example of a specific more

This is based on

for anyone who's built
this over in mode.

And then there's a URL pattern,
/API/, followed by anything.

And then the behavior here

304.43.text:
These methods are what
we call strategies.

310.21.text:
Typically, you need to
think pretty carefully

312.10.text:
about exactly what
behavior you want

314.80.text:
for different parts
of your application.

318.18.text:
So, you need to choose
a different strategy

324.09.text:
SW-Toolbox comes with five
built-in strategies, fastest,

332.59.text: Let's go over what they are.

338.10.text:
With the fastest strategy,
a request comes in,

341.81.text:
and we race the
network and the cache.

344.61.text:
Whichever one is going
to come back first

346.32.text: is going to return to the page.

348.56.text:
In this example,
the cache is going

350.30.text:
to come back first, which
is probably pretty obvious.

355.45.text:
win if it wasn't in the
cache in the first place.

359.35.text:
If and when the
network ever does

361.20.text:
succeed, it updates the cache
so that the next time this

363.53.text:
happens, even if it
goes to the cache,

365.53.text:
it's a slightly fresher
version of the resource.

369.91.text:
This is good for stuff
that you want to be fast

372.53.text:
but is allowed to be maybe
a little bit out of date.

376.38.text:
And just as a note, because this
one always uses the network,

379.46.text:
if your goal is to save
your user's data plan,

382.43.text:
this is obviously not
necessarily the best thing

384.45.text: to do for all your resources.

391.59.text:
Request comes in, first
of all we try the network,

394.56.text:
and we give that time to succeed
or fail, and only if it fails,

399.88.text:
do we then go to the cache
and return that to the page.

403.95.text:
And if the network
request does succeed,

405.87.text:
that updates the cache
even though we're not

407.85.text:
coming from the cache
this time around.

409.51.text:
So the next time we try
it when we're offline

411.50.text:
or whether the network times
out, we get more a up to date

You can imagine, fastest
and networkFirst,

425.22.text:
If you imagine a Twitter
client, then when you first

428.26.text:
load your application,
your highest priority

431.49.text:
is getting stuff on screen so
the user has your application.

435.35.text:
So, perhaps you use fastest
to load the latest tweets

438.54.text:
because it's better to show
old tweets than show no tweets.

441.77.text:
Whereas when the user
does a pull to refresh,

445.22.text:
that's a pretty strong
signal they actually

449.05.text:
So, go to the network,
and only go from the cache

451.92.text: if you can't use the network.

456.74.text:
There's an important
extra option to this one

459.05.text:
because it turns out
that on mobile devices,

461.90.text:
that network timeout
can be two minutes.

465.08.text:
So, if you have Li-Fi, and
your device is absolutely

468.38.text:
convinced it has a connection
but it doesn't really,

472.06.text:
then you can have
some sort of action,

474.90.text:
and it can be two
minutes before you even

479.00.text:
So, we've added an option
for the networkFirst strategy

482.80.text:
that lets you say give a
more reasonable time out.

486.12.text:
Here we're saying,
after five seconds.

487.96.text:
I don't care about
what's on the network.

498.86.text:
Only if it's not there
do we go to the network.

501.87.text:
Sort of the opposite
of networkFirst.

504.87.text:
Again, the network
will update the cache,

507.27.text:
but one of the important
things to realize here

509.62.text:
is that once that network
request has succeeded once,

512.92.text:
it will be in the cache,
and so the cache will

514.90.text:
be consulted every time, and
it will never be updated.

519.26.text:
This is still pretty
good for some cases.

521.37.text:
If you have versioned URLs,
if you have some reason where

524.14.text:
the URL will change whenever
the content changes,

527.65.text: this will work fine for that.

531.57.text:
And this might be
for things that you

535.57.text:
want to be able to cache,
the things that don't change

538.01.text:
but aren't part of

The example I've been
using is blog posts.

543.55.text:
You don't want to download
10 years worth of blog post's

545.88.text:
the very first time
someone comes to your blog,

547.89.text:
but if they have
been to your site

549.31.text:
and downloaded a few posts, it's
reasonable to keep them around.

556.52.text:
This is go to the cache, and
if it's not in the cache, fail.

This is good for the
stuff that you precached

565.10.text:
And then networkOnly, go to

This is what you got

571.22.text:
and the only real
reason to use this

is that if you've overridden

you to go back to the original

And if those don't do

you can also define

Here we have a function I've

What this does is
it takes a request,

599.28.text:
and it will try and fetch

603.06.text:
And if it fails, it will

605.40.text:
but it won't try and
respond with that a cache

611.55.text:
It will always respond
with this fallback.jpg.

615.36.text:
You can use this, for example,
if you have hundreds of profile

619.41.text:
Perhaps it's not actually
that important to have

621.66.text:
that in your offline
experience, and you

623.33.text:
don't want to fill the user's
device with those images,

628.14.text:
so you have a single image
that uses a fallback instead.

And to make this
useful, you have

632.47.text:
to make sure you've

and then set up a route

It's just the same as

of using toolbox dot whatever,

And finally on toolbox, you can

651.57.text:
By default, when

or when you use cacheOnly,

the cache that it uses

It's a default cache that

You can on an ad hoc

I want to use a different

And SW-Toolbox will go in

700.20.text:
Something we've kind of glossed
over there with SW-Toolbox

702.83.text:
is that that precaching
step is actually trickier

710.03.text:
One is that in order to
get a new install event,

714.07.text:
you need to change the
service worker script.

716.52.text:
Not something that service
worker script imports,

719.04.text:
but the actual, original
service worker script.

721.03.text:
So you have to remember
to actually update

722.78.text:
that every time you do a
release that changes some

726.43.text:
of the resource even if
the service worker itself,

729.98.text:
the logic, doesn't
need to change.

732.91.text:
Another problem is that when
the install event happens,

736.41.text:
SW-Toolbox will take
all those resources

738.44.text:
and just download them all
again even if none of them

746.56.text:
You also have to maintain
a list of which resources

752.04.text:
It would be quite easy to miss
something out of that array

754.99.text:
and then find that
in your next release,

757.81.text:
your offline experience is
slightly broken because a file

767.25.text:
So, we created a tool to help
with this called SW-Precache.

771.61.text:
What this does is it takes
a few simple options,

774.29.text:
and it writes a
service worker for you.

776.46.text:
It's something you can
stick in your build step.

779.56.text:
You tell it which files
you want to cache,

781.36.text:
it will take a hash of each
file along with the file name,

785.17.text:
and write those directly
into the service worker.

788.01.text:
So if any of your resources
change, the hash will change,

791.27.text:
the service worker
itself will change,

792.86.text: and you'll get a new install.

795.71.text:
It also means that when
an install event fires,

798.46.text:
the service worker has a list
of every resource with its hash

802.02.text:
so it can compare it to what it
already has and only download

805.43.text:
things that have
changed or are new.

814.08.text:
This can be used as a command
line tool, installable

817.10.text:
via node, and then you run
we-precache, and here's

824.51.text:
You say where the root

and it will just precache

You can also use it as a

839.02.text:
You say which service worker

and then you can

this glob pattern to say

And if you're wondering whether

rules that you

This is great for

if you want to do

You could let

932.84.text:
Just to reiterate, should I

What this will do is it will

But it also allows you to get

issues and some of

getting into a state where

Service worker won't actually

SW-AppCache behavior is

As an example of something

1334.52.text:
So, the Chrome team built one,
and we called it Lighthouse.

1338.84.text:
This is both a Chrome extension
and a node-based command line

1341.88.text:
tool which has a whole
bunch of different tests

1344.31.text:
in it that it runs on your site
and gives you advice on things

1351.54.text:
It also has this very cool,
professional-looking logo.

1357.55.text:
As a Chrome extension,
you load up your page,

1360.03.text:
you click the
button, and then it

1362.88.text:
will reload the
page a few times,

1365.24.text:
connect with the remote
debugging protocol,

1369.88.text:
gather a whole bunch of metrics,
and then spit out this report.

1374.51.text:
It'll give you a score
which will give you

1378.56.text:
a vague idea of what it
thinks of your application,

1381.60.text:
and it will tell you anywhere
that it thinks that you

1386.55.text:
And also has this
best practices section

1388.79.text:
that is things that it's
not going to score you on.

1390.98.text:
Maybe you don't actually need to
do these things, but if you do,

1394.77.text:
It just gives you
a bit of a guide.

1399.42.text:
You can also run it as
a command line tool.

1402.70.text:
Just for anyone who's
thinking of typing in URLs

1405.10.text:
they see on the screen,
airhorner.com makes a noise.

1408.25.text:
I give this talk at
I/O, and about 30

1410.01.text:
seconds after this slide
came up, someone was like--

1415.12.text:
So you run it on
the command line,

1417.06.text:
and by default, it will output
pretty printed to the console.

1422.78.text:
You can also output
JSON that you

1424.34.text:
can pause yourself
or the same HTML

1432.29.text:
It's also requireable
as a node module,

1434.46.text:
so you can say lighthouse,
and then the URL,

1437.73.text:
and that returns a promise
which resolves with the JSON

1440.70.text:
that you would have got
from the command line tool.

1443.53.text:
And obviously, the
CLI and node module

1446.87.text:
are both good ways
of adding Lighthouse

1449.68.text:
to your regular tasks or
continuous integration.

1456.58.text:
I'd like to draw attention to
the big Alpha in the corner

1460.58.text:
I just want to be clear
that this is early stages.

1463.38.text: None of the rules are final.

1464.75.text:
I'm sure there's a
lot of discussion

1466.41.text:
to be had about
what the rules say

1470.85.text:
If you would like to
contribute to that discussion,

1472.97.text:
or better yet,
contribute pull requests,

1474.81.text: you can find us on GitHub.

1477.12.text:
And I'd also like to point out
that this currently only works

1479.66.text:
in Chrome 52+, which
is currently in beta.

1490.99.text:
are made possible by

1493.21.text:
They're made practical

1497.75.text:
There are a whole bunch of

1499.87.text:
out there from Google and

Chrome DevTools is

and Lighthouse attempts to

1511.42.text:
That's probably a bit too
